attributes.title: Rivals across situations
attributes.description: This is the OSF page related to a project where rival characteristics were examined across situations

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
There are some variable included for sample description. 

We propose to check what happens to any found effect if we control for:
* Relationship status (0: not in a relationship (or less than six months); 1: in a romantic relationship for more than six months. (Note that in our coding scheme more than 6 months, will be counted as a year).
* Having had experienced something similar as in the scenario (Yes/No). (The logic for this is derived by studies suggesting that those who experience infidelity would respond differently (or not) (see e.g. Berman and Frazier 2005; Edlund et al 2006; Harris, 2002; Zengel et al. 2013). 
* The degree to which participants believe the there was a good likelihood of a romantic or sexual aspect to their interactions? Either currently or as a future possibility? (Yes/no)

References

Berman, M. I., and Frazier, P. A. (2005). Relationship power and betrayal experience as predictors of reactions to infidelity. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 31(12), 1617-1627.
Edlund, J. E., Heider, J. D., Scherer, C. R., Farc, M. M., & Sagarin, B. J. (2006). Sex differences in jealousy in response to actual infidelity. Evolutionary Psychology, 4(1), 147470490600400137.
Harris, C. R. (2002). Sexual and romantic jealousy in heterosexual and homosexual adults. Psychological Science, 13(1), 7–12. https://doi.org/10.1111/1467-9280.00402
Zengel, B., Edlund, J. E., & Sagarin, B. J. (2013). Sex differences in jealousy in response to infidelity: Evaluation of demographic moderators in a national random sample. Personality and Individual Differences, 54(1), 47-51.

sample.value:
We will collect 3 samples.
1) An in class sample during a lecture on Feb 3rd.
2) An online sample (perhaps supplemented via our university's SONA pool - whereby our students receive credit). This will run for around 6 weeks.
3) A sample of attendees to a University open day event on  Feb. 22nd.

We aim for minimum 250 participants (125 women / 125 men). That would allow 50 per 'non-romantic' cell in our design, which should be sufficient for our Bayesian estimation procedure.

analyses.value:
We will run a multivariate Bayesian Regression Model if possible via using BRMS (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/brms/index.html). This will be followed up by univariate models to determine where the differences lie. If context matters we should find an effect of context (parent/close friend/romantic context). Similarly, we'll be able to examine the boundary condition of whether the sex of the rival matters by investigating the friendship scenario.  This model will account for the 3 different samples below via a random intercept (and if possible also account for the different scenarios via a random intercept). So, ideally a model with 2 random intercepts (one for vignette and one for location). Even though we considered more complex models (e.g., 'Keeping it maximal' - Barr et al. 2013 - we don't believe this is tractable). We will evaluate parameter estimates and their 95% credible intervals

An alternative model would be a permutational model via a permutation MANOVA (http://search.r-project.org/library/vegan/html/adonis.html). This would be followed by Permutational ANOVAs.

Either model could be presented in the paper.
  
Reference.
Barr, D. J., Levy, R., Scheepers, C., & Tily, H. J. (2013). Random effects structure for confirmatory hypothesis testing: Keep it maximal. Journal of Memory and Language, 68(3), 255–278. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jml.2012.11.001

outliers.value:
We will exclude participants who do not indicate their gender to be either male or female.
The analyses will be restricted to heterosexual participants. If there is a minimum of 50 respondents of a different sexual orientation in each cell then we will present analyses on these as well.

dependent.value: 24 items on rival characteristics on a 1-5 scale as in Zurriaga et al. 2018.

conditions.value:
There are 6 scenarios. Every participant will evaluate the romantic scenario and then 1 of the remaining non-romantic scenarios. The order is randomised.

1) Romantic: rival is same sex as participant. 'Partner' in scenario is appropriate to participant's stated sexual orientation.

2) Parent: rival is same sex as the participant. We ask participant whether they envisaged a male or female parent. We are not interested in an opposite-sex rival here as we are testing that particular 'boundary' in scenarios 3 - 6 below.

3) Male friend: rival is opposite sex

4) Male friend: rival is same sex

5) Female friend: rival is opposite sex

6) Female friend: rival is same sex

hypothesis.value:
What is the boundary condition for hypothesised romantic rival effects? Do individuals rate rival characteristics differently depending on context (romantic/friendship/parent)  and/or the sex of the rival?
There are competing hypotheses: one being that rival characteristics will be evaluated largely independent from context, and one suggesting that especially in romantic contexts rival characteristics will be evaluated as more important (and then particularly those traits which would be relevant to the opposite sex - in line with Zurriaga et al. (2018).

We are less interested in sex differences (and similarities) but they could be expected to broadly align with those Zurriaga et al. (2018).

Reference.

Zurriaga, R., González-Navarro, P., Buunk, A. P., & Dijkstra, P. (2018). Jealousy at work: The role of rivals’ characteristics. Scandinavian Journal of Psychology, 59(4), 443–450. https://doi.org/10.1111/sjop.12443


The questionnaire is included.

attributes.title: Information sampling in 2 beads tasks and 1 box task

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Effect of finite versus infinite sequentially observed random variables in optimal-stopping decision. .

The study tries to research if the decision making about optimal stopping in not-maths/statistics trained people are influenced by the same type of data exposed as finite versus infinite set of variables.

sample.value:
Sample size: Recruit N=70

Considering a possible correlation between .3 to .4, an error of 5% and a power of 80%, for a dependent sample t-test we would require 59 participants. We will use around 70, simply because we have the possibility to do that. 
I guess I am going to find “medium effect” as a result of this experiment.

analyses.value: The amount of drawings needed by the participants to take the probabilistic decisions in the beads test and box task tests will be compared as Pearson correlation. We will conduct a dependent samples t-test since all participants shall undergo both tasks. The alpha level used will be .05 as conventional. We will conduct two-sided tests.

outliers.value: The participants will be mostly students recruited at the Arctic University of Norway, Tromsø, Norway, hence students older than 18 younger than 55 years. Some individuals other than students may partake in the experiment, after personal request of the experimenter. Requirements are normal or corrected eyesight, proficiency in English language with no neurological condition in an acute stage, or (il)legal drugs consumed during the last 3 months. They will have to sign a consent before participating. All data will be collected in one day, each participant tested on different computers which will be programmed with a different version of the Beads and Box test, as described. Participants can anytime withdraw at will without adding motivation.

dependent.value: Numbers of drawing a participant will decide to pluck from two different sets of data -the one finite and the second infinite- will be counted before the participant returns the requested probabilistic decision. This will be measured and performed completely through a computer system.

conditions.value: There are two tasks: the beads task and the box task, both performed on a computer screen. In both tasks, the participant has to guess which of two given possible colours will be more represented for the sequence of items appearing on the screen.  In the bead task, pressing a button will make the items appear in line one by one with its colour revealed. The participant can press the button an “infinite” number of times, hence dealing with infinite items to make his or her decision about the most represented colour of them. In the box task, however, the participant will be given a limited amount of items altogether with disguised colour; pressing the button will reveal the colour of a single item of the group. Here, the participant shall have to make again his probability decision between the two colours, but this time guessing from a finite set of items. The point of the experiment is to see how many items will be disguised before deciding which colour is the most represented.

hypothesis.value:
We hypothesise that there will be a significant difference in how much information participants need to sample when drawing from  “finite” versus “infinite” sets of data,  before making a probabilistic decision.
We predict as well a positive correlation between the draws to decision of both tasks.

attributes.title: Whistle-blowing on Harassment Bribes: Financial Rewards, Judicial Accuracy, and Evidence Thresholds
attributes.description: The goal of our research is to evaluate the effectiveness of financial rewards in increasing whistle-blowing of corrupt activities. We include for perverse incentives where citizens  can report honest officials and see if reward schemes are exploited. Manipulations on judicial accuracy and evidence threshold enable us to evaluate the impact of financial rewards and emergence of reward misuse under different judicial regimes.

q1.value: Whistle-blowing on Harassment Bribes: Financial Rewards, Judicial Accuracy, and Evidence Thresholds

q3.value: The goal of our research is to evaluate the effectiveness of financial rewards in increasing whistle-blowing of corrupt activities. We include for perverse incentives where citizens can report honest officials and see if reward schemes are exploited. Manipulations on judicial accuracy and evidence threshold enable us to evaluate the impact of financial rewards and emergence of reward misuse under different judicial regimes. Judicial regimes vary in the degree of evidence threshold they impose on whistle-blowers and in the degree of quality of judiciary i.e. likelihood of false positives (convicting innocent after a false report) and false negatives (exonerating a corrupt after a true report). The experiment comprises of a variant of the dictator game and the bribery game and a post experiment questionnaire. Corruption, in our experiment, arises when a public official asks a citizen to pay a bribe. The citizen moves next where he/she can refuse the bribe, pay the bribe, or pay the bribe and report it.

q4.value:
We expect citizens reporting to be higher when cost of reporting is small and vice versa.
We expect officials to ask for bribes more under judicial setting with high error rate and vice versa. Whistleblowing is expected to identify corrupt behaviour optimally under a more accurate judicial setting with high cost of reporting.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Our experiment involves a between subject design with 2 factors namely, judicial accuracy and evidence threshold captured by cost of reporting, each having two levels I.e. low and high.

q9.value: We invite subjects to the lab using the hroot system. At the start of the session we choose between the 4 possible treatments and then run that treatment.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants are recruited through the hroot system at the University of Essex's social science research lab, EsseXLab. They will be paid on average £12 for one hour of their participation.

q13.value: We estimate a sample size of 240 participants with 6o subjects in each treatment. We send invitations to more than 7000 potential subjects.

q14.value: We have chosen the sample size based on those selected under previous studies on corruption and whistleblowing.

q15.value: We will run experiments with approximately 20 subjects in each treatment and we will stop when have achieved the required sample size (which means 12 sessions in total.

question.value:
We will manipulate the level of evidence threshold which is captured by the cost of reporting. The planned levels are 150 points vs. 10 points.
We will also manipulate the level of judicial accuracy which is captured by the rate of type I and type II errors. The levels are 10% (high accuracy) and 40% (low accuracy).

The main outcome variables are,
1) Number of and the amount of bribes initiated under each treatment,
2) The number of bribes reported under each treatment.
3) The trend of bribe initiation and reporting under each treatment with finitely repeated play.

We will use non-parametric tests to check for mean differences of bribe initiation and bribe reporting under each treatment.
We will use a Probit regression to see if the likelihood of bribe demand is significantly different across high accuracy and low accuracy treatments even after controlling for factors like demographics, risk preferences and attitudes towards bribery etc.

q21.value: We will test mean difference and use the 5% level of significance. We will also estimate the marginal effects under Probit estimations.

attributes.title: Knowledgeability, Contextual Numerals and Scalar Implicature

q1.value: Knowledgeability, Contextual Numerals and Scalar Implicature

q2.value: Zheng Zhang, Edward Gibson, Leon Bergen, Rachel Ryskin, Alexander Paunov

q3.value:
"Some of the books were interesting." is typically interpreted to mean that a non-zero number of books was interesting but NOT ALL of the books were interesting, because the speaker would have said "all" if they were all interesting. This is a case of scalar implicature. Goodman and Stuhlmüller (2013) showed that comprehenders make this type of inference when the speaker has full knowledge (e.g., the speaker has read all 3 books) but the inference is (partly) cancelled when the speaker’s knowledge is limited (e.g., the speaker has only read 2 of the 3 books).

Previous work has also found that the online processing of “some” is slowed down when the speaker uses numerals to refer to small sets in the same context (Degen and Tanenhaus, 2015). 

In the present work, we explore the interaction between the knowledgeability of the speaker and the existence of contextual numerals in the offline processing of scalar implicature. In particular, we ask whether the use of numerals in the same context can affect offline processing of scalar implicature, by making comprehenders more aware of the more natural  alternative labels (e.g., Two of the books were interesting).

q4.value: We predict that the knowledgeability effect reported by Goodman and Stuhlmuller (2013) should be reduced when the surrounding context contains numerals. In other words we predict a significant interaction between knowledge state (knowledgeability) of the speaker and presence v. absence of numbers in the experimental context.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The factor "knowledgeability" is within subject and has 2 levels (full knowledge and partial knowledge). The factor "contextual numeral" is between subject and has 2 levels (with numerals and no numerals).
Each participant will receive 8 target trials (4 partial knowledge + 4 full knowledge) and 24 exposure trials.
Half of the participants will receive exposure trials with numerals, and the other half will receive exposure trials with no numerals.

q9.value: We will use Turkolizer software from Gibson, Piantadosi, and Fedorenko (2011) to randomly assign the trials to each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited on Amazon.com’s Mechanical Turk and complete the experiment for $3 dollars payment. People who meet the requirements (1)–(4) are eligible to participate in the experiment. 
(1) IP address inside the U.S.A.
(2) Have completed more than 100 surveys on Mechanical Turk. 
(3) Approval rate over 95%. 
(4) They must not have participated in our similar experiments before.

q13.value:
We will collect data from 300 participants.
Each participant will receive 8 target trials (4 partial knowledge + 4 full knowledge) and 24 exposure trials.
150 participants will receive exposure trials with numerals, and 150 participants will receive exposure trials with no numerals.

q14.value:
In a previous version of this experiment, we collected data until we reached the sample size of 240 participants. 
In the current study, we will analyze the data from the participants who meet all the requirements listed as follows. 1) Participants' native language is English. 2) They have completed at least 87.5% of the possibility rating questions. 3) Their accuracy on confirmation questions is at least 87.5%. 4) They are from the USA.
Based on the previous data from a previous experiment, about 82% of the people who participated in the experiment could meet all the above requirements. Therefore, in order to keep the same sample size as in the previous experiment, we decide to recruit 300 participants this time. (240/0.82≈293)

question.value:
We manipulate the speaker's knowledgeability and the existence of contextual numerals. 
The variable "knowledgeability" is within subject and has 2 levels: partial knowledge or full knowledge. The variable "contextual numeral" is between subject and has 2 levels: with numerals and no numerals. 
Each participant will receive 8 target trials (4 partial knowledge + 4 full knowledge) and 24 exposure trials (12 partial knowledge + 12 full knowledge). Half of the participants will receive exposure trials with numerals, and the other half will receive exposure trials with no numerals. 
More details: 
Each trial given to the participant is composed of three parts: a picture, a short paragraph of text, and three questions. 
An example critical trial is given as follows. 
First, a picture is shown to the participant. The picture consists of a character and 3 objects. In the full knowledge condition, 3 of the 3 objects are circled. 
Then, a paragraph of text follows the picture. The text first names the speaker and describes the objects and the relevant property: “Letters to Laura's company almost always have checks inside. Today Laura needs to find out whether the above letters have checks inside.”
Then it is followed by a speech act in which the speaker both declares the (sub)set of the objects he or she has observed and states that some objects have the property: “While pointing to the circled set of letters, Laura tells you, ‘I have now checked these letters and given what I saw, I can tell you that some of today's letters have checks inside.’ ”
Last, the question phase consists of three questions. The function of the first two questions is to confirm the participant has read the materials carefully and fully understood what is going on in the given scenario. Thus, the first two questions have correct answers. For example: “Did Laura look at all of today's letters?” (correct answer: yes) “Did Laura say that some of today's letters have checks inside?” (correct answer: yes) The third question asks the participant the likelihood of all the objects having the property. The answer to this question is the dependent factor we would analyze. “Assuming that the speaker is providing an accurate description of his/her knowledge, how likely is it that all of today's letters have checks inside? Please provide a probability percentage: ____%” 
How we manipulate the speaker’s knowledgeability and the contextual numerals:
Please see the attachment ("Manipulated variables description copy.txt") below, due to the word limit of this section.

What we will examine is listeners’ interpretation of a statement in which "some" may or may not trigger scalar implicature. The critical question will be "Assuming that the speaker is providing an accurate description of his/her knowledge, how likely is it that all of xxx (items) have the yyy (property)? Please provide a probability percentage: __%" 
This dependent variable ranges from 0% to 100%. If a listener responds with a lower percentage, they are more committed to the “some but not all” reading of “some”, whereas if they respond with a higher percentage, they are more committed to the “some and possibly all” reading by (partially) cancelling the standard implicature of “some”.

Effects of speaker’s perceptual access ("knowledgeability") and contextual numerals on probability ratings will be assessed via linear mixed-effects regression using the lme4 package in R (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2014).
The predictors are "knowledgeability" and "contextual numeral", as well as their interaction. The dependent variable is the rating of the likelihood of all the items having the property (participants' interpretation of scalar implicature).

q20.value: Knowledgeability and Numerals conditions will be sum coded (-0.5, 0.5).

q21.value: We will use the standard .05 alpha criterion for determining significance of the main effects and interaction.

q25.value:
We ran four previous versions of this experiment. The link to the preregistration of the previous experiments are osf.io/v7fx2, osf.io/ujc3m, osf.io/93wbh and osf.io/768nx.
In the first experiment, we found a pattern suggesting there was an interaction between the knowledgeability and the existence of numerals. In the second experiment, we slightly changed the experiment design: we added 8 exposure trials in each contextual numerals condition, making the ratio of exposure trials to critical trials increase from 2:1 to 3:1. We expected the change could make the No Numerals vs. With Numerals manipulation more salient and the hypothesized effects stronger. The predicted results were significant. In the third experiment, we adjusted the experiment materials to remove a potential confounding factor. In the first and second experiment, we had some large numbers in the fillers (e.g., "Robert needs to check whether 12 windows are closed."), whereas in the target trials the numbers were all three (e.g., "Zach needs to check whether 3 of the tickets have won"). This difference between "large numbers" vs. "small numbers" could be a confounding factor. Thus, in the third experiment, we changed all the numbers in the fillers to 3, 4 or 5, in order to ensure that the predicted interaction results from the existence/absence of the numerals rather than the difference between “large numbers” and “small numbers”. The predicted interaction was not significant, but the main effect of numerals was significant. We thought this could result from the fact that there were still numerals in the “no numerals” condition to indicate the total number of the items (e.g., “Zach needs to check whether 3 of the tickets have won.”). In the fourth experiment, we changed the experiment materials to remove this potential confounding factor: we got rid of the numerals in the materials in the “no-numerals” condition and instead used pictures to indicate the total number of the items and how many of them the character has checked. In addition, we got rid of all the exposure trials and kept only the critical trials. We expected the picture version could show the predicted effects without the more salient manipulation brought about by the exposure trials. But the predicted effects were not significant.  We concluded that fillers are needed in order to see the main effect of "some" for partial knowledge vs. full knowledge.  Thus, in this current study, we added back all the exposure trials. Also, we adjusted the critical trials so that they were all identical across the two conditions. We now just have the critical trials (all without number words) within our two sets of exposure trials.

registration_responses.q1: Knowledgeability, Contextual Numerals and Scalar Implicature
registration_responses.q2: Zheng Zhang, Edward Gibson, Leon Bergen, Rachel Ryskin, Alexander Paunov
registration_responses.q3:
"Some of the books were interesting." is typically interpreted to mean that a non-zero number of books was interesting but NOT ALL of the books were interesting, because the speaker would have said "all" if they were all interesting. This is a case of scalar implicature. Goodman and Stuhlmüller (2013) showed that comprehenders make this type of inference when the speaker has full knowledge (e.g., the speaker has read all 3 books) but the inference is (partly) cancelled when the speaker’s knowledge is limited (e.g., the speaker has only read 2 of the 3 books).

Previous work has also found that the online processing of “some” is slowed down when the speaker uses numerals to refer to small sets in the same context (Degen and Tanenhaus, 2015). 

In the present work, we explore the interaction between the knowledgeability of the speaker and the existence of contextual numerals in the offline processing of scalar implicature. In particular, we ask whether the use of numerals in the same context can affect offline processing of scalar implicature, by making comprehenders more aware of the more natural  alternative labels (e.g., Two of the books were interesting).
registration_responses.q4: We predict that the knowledgeability effect reported by Goodman and Stuhlmuller (2013) should be reduced when the surrounding context contains numerals. In other words we predict a significant interaction between knowledge state (knowledgeability) of the speaker and presence v. absence of numbers in the experimental context.

registration_responses.q8.question:
The factor "knowledgeability" is within subject and has 2 levels (full knowledge and partial knowledge). The factor "contextual numeral" is between subject and has 2 levels (with numerals and no numerals).
Each participant will receive 8 target trials (4 partial knowledge + 4 full knowledge) and 24 exposure trials.
Half of the participants will receive exposure trials with numerals, and the other half will receive exposure trials with no numerals.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited on Amazon.com’s Mechanical Turk and complete the experiment for $3 dollars payment. People who meet the requirements (1)–(4) are eligible to participate in the experiment. 
(1) IP address inside the U.S.A.
(2) Have completed more than 100 surveys on Mechanical Turk. 
(3) Approval rate over 95%. 
(4) They must not have participated in our similar experiments before.
registration_responses.q16.question:
We manipulate the speaker's knowledgeability and the existence of contextual numerals. 
The variable "knowledgeability" is within subject and has 2 levels: partial knowledge or full knowledge. The variable "contextual numeral" is between subject and has 2 levels: with numerals and no numerals. 
Each participant will receive 8 target trials (4 partial knowledge + 4 full knowledge) and 24 exposure trials (12 partial knowledge + 12 full knowledge). Half of the participants will receive exposure trials with numerals, and the other half will receive exposure trials with no numerals. 
More details: 
Each trial given to the participant is composed of three parts: a picture, a short paragraph of text, and three questions. 
An example critical trial is given as follows. 
First, a picture is shown to the participant. The picture consists of a character and 3 objects. In the full knowledge condition, 3 of the 3 objects are circled. 
Then, a paragraph of text follows the picture. The text first names the speaker and describes the objects and the relevant property: “Letters to Laura's company almost always have checks inside. Today Laura needs to find out whether the above letters have checks inside.”
Then it is followed by a speech act in which the speaker both declares the (sub)set of the objects he or she has observed and states that some objects have the property: “While pointing to the circled set of letters, Laura tells you, ‘I have now checked these letters and given what I saw, I can tell you that some of today's letters have checks inside.’ ”
Last, the question phase consists of three questions. The function of the first two questions is to confirm the participant has read the materials carefully and fully understood what is going on in the given scenario. Thus, the first two questions have correct answers. For example: “Did Laura look at all of today's letters?” (correct answer: yes) “Did Laura say that some of today's letters have checks inside?” (correct answer: yes) The third question asks the participant the likelihood of all the objects having the property. The answer to this question is the dependent factor we would analyze. “Assuming that the speaker is providing an accurate description of his/her knowledge, how likely is it that all of today's letters have checks inside? Please provide a probability percentage: ____%” 
How we manipulate the speaker’s knowledgeability and the contextual numerals:
Please see the attachment ("Manipulated variables description copy.txt") below, due to the word limit of this section.
registration_responses.q17.question:
What we will examine is listeners’ interpretation of a statement in which "some" may or may not trigger scalar implicature. The critical question will be "Assuming that the speaker is providing an accurate description of his/her knowledge, how likely is it that all of xxx (items) have the yyy (property)? Please provide a probability percentage: __%" 
This dependent variable ranges from 0% to 100%. If a listener responds with a lower percentage, they are more committed to the “some but not all” reading of “some”, whereas if they respond with a higher percentage, they are more committed to the “some and possibly all” reading by (partially) cancelling the standard implicature of “some”.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Effects of speaker’s perceptual access ("knowledgeability") and contextual numerals on probability ratings will be assessed via linear mixed-effects regression using the lme4 package in R (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2014).
The predictors are "knowledgeability" and "contextual numeral", as well as their interaction. The dependent variable is the rating of the likelihood of all the items having the property (participants' interpretation of scalar implicature).

attributes.title: Replication - Personality and Social Framing in Privacy Decision-Making: A Study on Cookie Acceptance

q1.value: Replication of Personality and Social Framing in Privacy Decision-Making: A Study on Cookie Acceptance

q3.value:
This study is a replication of "Personality and Social Framing in Privacy Decision-Making: A Study on Cookie Acceptance" by L.M.Conventry, D.Jeske, J.M.Blythe, J.Turland & P.Briggs published 2016 in frontiers in psychology (7;1341).
The study explores some of the framing influencers that affect privacy-related decision making, specifically in the context of accepting or rejecting cookies – a known issue in relation to privacy.

q4.value: In comparison to a base rate (control) which is likely to lean toward acceptance of cookies, participants’ responses will be affected by a social nudge, such that a low social norm (minority) reference will effectively nudge participants away from accepting cookies.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

Between subject design with 1 factor (social framing ) and 3 levels (control, minority social norm, majority social norm).
The dependent measure for the true task was cookie acceptance.

q9.value: Participants randomly allocated to one of the three cookie conditions by using the randomization-option on the website of socsisurvey.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through different Facebook groups from universities.
Participants must be students, because participants from the same occupational group allowed us to make sure that the participants would identify with the referent group mentioned in the social manipulations, in this case students.
They recruited through Facebook, because all users of the platform are regular users of the Internet.

q13.value: My target sample size ist 203 participants. I will attempt to recruit up to 250, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q14.value: I used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 Power to detect the effect of .276 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value: I manipulated the cookie-dialogs which presented social framing. The three levels of this categorical variable are: control (no social norm), minority social norm (37%), majority social norm (74%).
The outcome variable will be the cookie acceptance. We will measure this by asking participants "Do you want to use this option?" (with the options "Accept" and "don't accept")
I will use a Chi-square-analysis across the three conditions.( Cramer' V ) Then I will use a Chi-square analysis for pairwise comparisons (φ-coefficient).

q23.value: If a questionnaire does not completed, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: How do children learn new grammar from shared book reading?

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: How do children learn new grammar from shared book reading?: pre-analysis registration

other.value: This pre-registration is prior to analysis of the data: the data have been collected, but have not been analyzed (including summary statistics)

analyses.value:
A 2x2 between-subjects ANOVA will be conducted with school grade (2 levels: grade 1 and 2) and story condition (2 levels: same or different) as the independent variables, and performance improvement on the production and comprehension measures. This is conditional on the sample meeting the assumption of normality (e.g. tested by Kolmogrov-Smirnov test, or if the distribution forms a normal-like distribution, or using a transformation)
If the data largely violates the assumption, other non-parametric tests will be used, such as Kruskal-Wallis, to test whether there is a difference in improvement between the participants in the same story condition and different story condition.

outliers.value: Participants with scores below 2.5 standard deviation will be excluded.

dependent.value: The dependent variables are performance on the production and comprehension measures, and improvement from session 1 to 2. Production will be measured as either correct/incorrect production of passive voice. Comprehension will be either a correct/incorrect answer on a 2-choice task.

conditions.value: Participants will be assigned to either the same story condition or the different story condition. In each of the two conditions, there will be two groups so that the two stories are randomized between them (i.e. group A: same story A, group B: same story B, group C: A then B, group D: B then A)

hypothesis.value:
1. Children in Grade 2 will score higher on the production and comprehension tests than children in Grade 1 on both sessions.

2. Children in the different story condition would show greater performance improvement from session 1 to 2 on the production and comprehension tests than children in the same story condition.

attributes.title: The role of neighborhood collective efficacy in moderating internalizing and externalizing behaviors in adolescents who experienced maltreatment

q1.value: The role of neighborhood collective efficacy in moderating internalizing and externalizing behaviors in adolescents who experienced maltreatment

q3.value:
Child maltreatment is associated with an increased risk of adverse outcomes, including aggression, depressive symptoms, and anxiety symptoms (Cicchetti & Toth, 2005; Hildyard & Wolfe, 2002). It is important for prevention and intervention efforts to identify factors that may reduce risk of adverse outcomes in children who have experienced maltreatment. Neighborhood collective efficacy (NCE) is the perception of the social connection in the neighborhood, which includes a combination of social cohesion (i.e., trust in neighbors) and informal social control (i.e., neighbors’ willingness to intervene in situations) (Sampson et al. 1997). Neighborhood collective efficacy (NCE) is associated with lower externalizing and internalizing problems among diverse groups of individuals. The two components of NCE, informal social control and social cohesion, are uniquely associated with lower externalizing and internalizing problems (Dawson et al., 2019; Kim et al., 2019; Kingsbury et al., 2019). Social cohesion buffers the effect of stressful life events on adolescent externalizing problems (e.g., aggression) and internalizing problems (e.g., depression and anxiety) (Kingsbury 2019; Kim 2019). However, limited studies have examined moderating effect of NCE or its components on internalizing problems and externalizing problems in individuals who have experienced child maltreatment. The study is unique since we are examining the individual components of NCE and maltreatment, a potent relationship stressor. The protective effect of NCE may operate differently in the context of maltreatment compared to other types of stress. In addition, few studies have examined associations of NCE with both internalizing and externalizing behaviors in the same study.
 Research has found that higher NCE or social cohesion is related to lower externalizing behaviors among maltreated youths (Kotch et al. 2014; Yonas et al. 2010). One study found that youths who experienced neglect were buffered on aggressive outcomes by NCE but not youths who experienced physical or sexual abuse (Yonas et al. 2010). These results suggest that NCE may not buffer different types of maltreatment in the same manner. Furthermore, another study found a main effect such that higher social cohesion but not informal social control was associated with lower externalizing problems among youths who experienced neglect (Kotch et al. 2014). Additionally, there is only one study to our knowledge that has examined if neighborhood social cohesion has a moderating effect on internalizing behaviors. Using data from the Project of Human Development of Chicago Neighborhoods, the authors founds that higher neighborhood social cohesion was related to lower internalizing behaviors but not externalizing behaviors among youths that experienced physical aggression towards them by a parent (Riina, Martin, & Brooks-Gunn, 2014). It was also demonstrated that social cohesion did not buffer children younger than 11 years old from internalizing behaviors; however, this buffering effect was seen in 11-year-old children and older. 
Since Riina and colleagues’ (2014) study only had parent report about parent-child physical aggression history, it will be beneficial to examine the moderating effect of NCE in a sample that used Child Protective Services (CPS) reports such as other studies that examined externalizing behaviors (Kotch et al. 2014; Yonas et al. 2010). There are mixed findings about the potential protective effects of social cohesion and informal social control among different maltreatment types. Thus, it is important to further examine these components of NCE individually. Furthermore, there is limited work that examined how the severity of stressors might moderate the associations between NCE and adverse outcomes. One study found that although there was no direct association between NCE and externalizing symptoms, NCE did buffer externalizing behaviors among maltreated adolescents who experienced bereavement (Sasser et al., 2019). Thus, NCE might still be an effective protective factor even in the context of high stress. 
Using the Fragile Families and Child Wellbeing Study (FFCWS), a sample of nearly 5000 individuals with prospective measures of abuse and neglect behaviors from birth through adolescence, we will test the hypothesis that NCE moderates the association of maltreatment with internalizing and externalizing problems. We hypothesize that maltreatment type and severity will moderate the buffering effect of NCE. However, the FFCWS uses parent report of abuse and neglect behaviors; we will then replicate the findings from the FFCWS dataset with another dataset. The Longitudinal Studies on Child Abuse and Neglect (LONGSCAN) dataset, an agency-referred sample of approximately 1300 maltreated and at-risk youth, will be used to replicate the findings of FFCWS. The proposed analyses will increase our understanding of the potential buffering nature of NCE for youths who have experienced maltreatment.

q4.value:
Aim 1: To examine the association of maltreatment severity by type (i.e., neglect, emotional maltreatment, and abuse) with internalizing and externalizing behaviors at age 15 or 16.
Hypothesis 1: It is expected that adolescents who experienced neglect will have higher internalizing and externalizing behaviors, especially as severity of neglect increases. It is expected that adolescent who experienced emotional maltreatment will have higher externalizing and internalizing behaviors, especially as severity of emotional maltreatment increases. It is expected that adolescents who experienced abuse will have higher externalizing and internalizing behaviors, especially as severity of abuse increases.

Aim 2: To examine the association of NCE with internalizing and externalizing behaviors at age 15 or 16. 
Hypothesis 2: It is expected that higher level of NCE will be associated with lower internalizing and externalizing behaviors. 

Aim 3: To examine whether maltreatment severity by type (i.e., abuse, neglect, emotional maltreatment) predicts the moderating effect of NCE on internalizing and externalizing behaviors at age 15 or 16.
Hypothesis 3: It is expected that there will be an interaction between severity of maltreatment type and NCE. 
Internalizing behaviors: It is expected that at higher levels of NCE, there will not be an association between neglect and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between neglect and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that at higher levels of NCE, there will not be an association between emotional maltreatment and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between emotional maltreatment and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that for both higher and lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between abuse and internalizing behaviors. However, there will be a stronger association between abuse and internalizing behaviors at low levels of NCE.
Externalizing behavior: It is expected that at higher levels of NCE, there will not be an association between neglect and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between neglect and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that at higher levels of NCE, there will not be an association between emotional maltreatment and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between emotional maltreatment and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that for both higher and lower levels of NCE, there will be an association between abuse and externalizing behaviors. However, there will be a stronger association between abuse and externalizing behaviors at low levels of NCE.

Exploratory aim 1: To examine whether the timing of maltreatment severity by type moderates the effect of NCE on internalizing and externalizing behaviors at age 15 or 16. 
Hypothesis 1: We will create an early maltreatment variable and a late maltreatment variable. In FFCWS, early maltreatment will be ages 1-5 and late maltreatment will be ages 9-15. In LONGSCAN, early maltreatment will be ages 0-6 and late maltreatment will be ages 7-16.
Internalizing behavior: It is expected that for both higher and lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between early neglect and internalizing behaviors. However, there will be a stronger association between early neglect and internalizing behavior at low levels of NCE. It is expected that at higher levels of NCE, there will not be an association between late neglect and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between late neglect and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that for both higher and lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between early emotional maltreatment and internalizing behaviors. However, there will be a stronger association between early emotional maltreatment and internalizing behavior at low levels of NCE. It is expected that at higher levels of NCE, there will not be an association between late emotional maltreatment and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between late emotional maltreatment and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that for both higher and lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between early abuse and internalizing behaviors. However, there will be a stronger association between early abuse and internalizing behavior at low levels of NCE. It is expected that for both higher and lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between late abuse and internalizing behaviors. However, there will be a stronger association between late abuse and internalizing behavior at low levels of NCE.
Externalizing behavior: It is expected that for both higher and lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between early neglect and externalizing behaviors. However, there will be a stronger association between early neglect and externalizing behavior at low levels of NCE. It is expected that at higher levels of NCE, there will not be an association between late neglect and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between late neglect and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that for both higher and lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between early emotional maltreatment and externalizing behaviors. However, there will be a stronger association between early emotional maltreatment and externalizing behavior at low levels of NCE. It is expected that at higher levels of NCE, there will not be an association between late emotional maltreatment and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between late emotional maltreatment and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that for both higher and lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between early abuse and externalizing behaviors. However, there will be a stronger association between early abuse and externalizing behavior at low levels of NCE. It is expected that for both higher and lower levels of NCE, there will be a positive association between late abuse and externalizing behaviors. However, there will be a stronger association between late abuse and externalizing behavior at low levels of NCE.

Exploratory aim 2: To examine whether the NCE components, social cohesion and informal social control, will moderate the effect of maltreatment severity on internalizing and externalizing behaviors at age 15 or 16. 
Hypothesis 2: Social cohesion: It is expected that neglect and internalizing behaviors will not be associated with one another at higher levels of social cohesion. At lower levels of social cohesion, neglect and internalizing behaviors will show a positive association. It is expected that neglect and externalizing behaviors will not be associated with one another at higher levels of social cohesion. At lower levels of social cohesion, neglect and externalizing behaviors will show a positive association. It is expected that emotional maltreatment and internalizing behaviors will not be associated with one another at higher levels of social cohesion. At lower levels of social cohesion, emotional maltreatment and internalizing behaviors will show a positive association. It is expected that emotional maltreatment and externalizing behaviors will not be associated with one another at higher levels of social cohesion. At lower levels of social cohesion, emotional maltreatment and externalizing behaviors will show a positive association. Abuse and internalizing behaviors will not be associated with one another at higher levels of social cohesion. It is expected that at lower levels of social cohesion, there will be a positive association between abuse and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that social cohesion will not moderate the association between abuse and externalizing behaviors.
Informal social control: Informal social control is not predicted to moderate the association between neglect and externalizing behaviors or between emotional maltreatment and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that informal social control will not moderate the association between neglect and internalizing behaviors or between emotional maltreatment and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that at higher levels of informal social control, there will be no association between abuse and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of informal social control, there will be a positive association between abuse and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that at higher levels of informal social control, there will be no association between abuse and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of informal social control, there will be a positive association between abuse and internalizing behaviors.

Exploratory aim 3: To test whether there is a sex difference on the moderating effect of NCE between maltreatment and internalizing and externalizing behaviors at age 15 or age 16.
Hypothesis 3: There has been mixed findings on sex differences in both NCE with internalizing behaviors and externalizing behaviors. 
Internalizing behaviors: Two studies of adolescents found the moderating effect of NCE between social disorder or exposure to violence and internalizing behaviors among females (Browning et al., 2013, 2014), but another study found moderating effect of NCE between stress and internalizing problems among males only (Sharma et al., 2019). With these mixed findings, we have no a priori hypotheses on the potential sex differences on the effect of NCE between maltreatment and internalizing behaviors. 
Externalizing behaviors: Wilkinson and colleagues (2019) showed that there were no sex differences in the moderating effect of NCE on frequency of delinquent behaviors among maltreated adolescents. Thus, it is predicted that there will not be any sex differences on the moderating effect of NCE on the association between maltreatment and externalizing behaviors.

question.value:
FFCWS:
Data collection: The FFCWS is a large longitudinal study representative of children born in large cities in the United States. The participants were born between 1998-2000 and were recruited at birth from 20 different cities. The FFCWS prioritized recruiting unmarried mothers since the goals of this study is to understand families and children from unmarried parents.  Both parents were asked to interview. If the father did not participate in the study, then the mother was asked questions about the father. Families were interviewed after their child was born, when their child was 1-year old, 3-years-old, 5-years-old, 9-years-old, and 15-years-old. There are many measures that were examined in these interviews by parents and/or primary caregiver and child (depending on age). In the interviews, mothers and/or primary caregivers were asked about their perception of the neighborhood and maltreatment experienced by their child. The demographic questionnaire, Neighborhood Collective Efficacy scale, and the Parent-Child Conflict Tactics Scales were given to mothers and/or primary caregivers. At age 15, adolescents completed self-report measures on their anxiety symptoms, depression symptom, and delinquency behaviors. The Brief Symptoms Inventory 18, the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale, and the Delinquency Behavior questionnaire were given to adolescents.

LONGSCAN:
Data collection: The LONGSCAN is a longitudinal study following children with different levels of risk for maltreatment. Participants were recruited at age 4 years from 5 different cities. Depending on the study site, participants were either recruited from another study, recruited from a tracking program, recruited from being reported to CPS, or recruited as a control (e.g., similar neighborhood background). Three cities recruited children from already existing samples and the other cities also recruited from other groups. The goal of this study was to understand families and children that are at risk of maltreatment or have experienced maltreatment. Primary caregivers were interviewed when their child was 4-year old, 6-years-old, 8-years-old, 12-years-old, 14-years-old, and 16-years-old. Parents and/or primary caregiver and child (depending on age) were interviewed. At age 16 of the child, primary caregivers were asked about their perception of the neighborhood, the Quality of Neighborhood, Residential Stability & Organizational and Religious Affiliation questionnaire. At age 16, adolescents completed self-report questionnaires on their trauma symptoms, and their delinquent and violent behaviors. Adolescents completed the Trauma Symptom Checklist for Children, and the Delinquent and Violent Behavior measure. Additionally, CPS records were regularly reviewed from birth through age 18 and were recoded with both the National Incidence Study coding and the Modified Maltreatment Classification System (MMCS; Barnett, Manly, & Cicchetti, 1993).

Stepwise linear regression models will be conducted in both FFCWS and LONGSCAN using SPSS version 25. 

14.1 FFCWS
Main models. The FFCWS dataset will be analyzed first with the 2 main models and then 3 exploratory models. In the two main models, the following independent variables will be entered into Step 1 of the stepwise linear model: abuse severity, neglect severity, NCE, covariates. The two interactions (abuse severity x NCE, and neglect severity x NCE) will be calculated after centering abuse severity, neglect severity, and NCE at zero, and these interactions will be entered into Step 2. The first model will have internalizing behaviors as the dependent variable, and the second model will be the same as the first model except that the dependent variable will be externalizing behaviors. We will use the Johnson-Neyman procedure (D’Alonzo, K. T., 2004) to examine regions of significance for significant interactions.

14.2 LONGSCAN
Main models. The LONGSCAN dataset will be analyzed after the FFCWS analyses with the 2 main models and then 3 exploratory models to replicate the findings from FFCWS. In the two main models, the following independent variables will be entered into Step 1 of the stepwise linear model: abuse severity, neglect severity, emotional maltreatment severity, NCE, and covariates. The three two-way interactions (abuse severity x NCE, neglect severity x NCE, and emotional maltreatment severity x NCE) will be calculated after centering abuse severity, neglect severity, emotional maltreatment severity, and NCE at zero, and these interactions will be entered into Step 2. The first model will have internalizing behaviors as the dependent variable, and the second model will be the same as the first model except that the dependent variable will be externalizing behaviors. We will use the Johnson-Neyman procedure (D’Alonzo, K. T., 2004) to examine regions significance for significant interactions.

FFCWS
Exploratory models. Stepwise linear regression models will be conducted to test the influence of 1) timing of maltreatment, 2) the separate components of NCE (i.e., social cohesion and informal social control), and 3) sex.
To test whether timing of maltreatment has an influence on the effect of NCE on internalizing and externalizing behaviors, we will calculate severity of each maltreatment type similar to the main models except we will calculate them into 2 groups: early and late. The early variable will be composed by calculating the total severity from age 1-5 for each maltreatment type while late variable will be composed by calculating the total severity from age 9-15 for each maltreatment type. The first separate stepwise linear regression model will be conducted with internalizing behaviors as the dependent variable and the second stepwise linear regression will be conducted with externalizing behavior as the dependent variable. The stepwise regressions will have step 1 all the independent variables (early abuse severity, late abuse severity, early neglect severity, late neglect severity, and NCE), including the covariates. Step 2 will include the interaction terms (i.e., early abuse severity x NCE, late abuse severity x NCE, early neglect severity x NCE, late neglect severity x NCE). 
To test whether there is a difference between the types of NCE, social cohesion and informal social control will be examined separately instead of combined as NCE. Once again, two separate models will be conducted for the dependent variables: internalizing behaviors and externalizing behaviors. Step 1 will include the independent variables (social cohesion, informal social control, abuse severity, neglect severity) and the covariates. Step 2 will include the interaction terms (i.e., abuse severity x social cohesion, neglect severity x social cohesion, abuse severity x informal social control, neglect severity x informal social control). 
To test whether there is a sex difference on the moderating effect of NCE, two 3-way interactions will be examined (i.e., abuse severity x NCE x sex, and neglect severity x NCE x sex) in Step 3 of the model. All independent variables will be in Step 1 and all 2-way interactions between abuse severity or neglect severity, NCE, and sex will be in Step 2. Sex differences will be tested in two separate models, one with internalizing symptoms as the dependent variable and one with externalizing symptoms as the dependent variable.

LONGSCAN
Exploratory models. Stepwise linear regression models will be conducted to test the influence of 1) timing of maltreatment, 2) the separate components of NCE (i.e., social cohesion and informal social control), and 3) sex.
To test whether timing of maltreatment has an influence on the effect of NCE on internalizing and externalizing behaviors, we will calculate severity of each maltreatment type similar to the main models except we will calculate them into 2 groups: early and late. The early variable will be composed by calculating the total severity from age 0-6 for each maltreatment type while late variable will be composed by calculating the total severity from age 7-16 for each maltreatment type. The first separate stepwise linear regression model will be conducted with internalizing behaviors as the dependent variable and the second stepwise linear regression will be conducted with externalizing behavior as the dependent variable. The stepwise regressions will have step 1 all the independent variables (early abuse severity, late abuse severity, early neglect severity, late neglect severity, early emotional maltreatment severity, late emotional maltreatment severity, and NCE), including the covariates. Step 2 will include the interaction terms (i.e., early abuse severity x NCE, late abuse severity x NCE, early neglect severity x NCE, late neglect severity x NCE, early emotional maltreatment severity x NCE, late emotional maltreatment severity x NCE).
To test whether there is a difference between the types of NCE, social cohesion and informal social control will be examined separately instead of combined as NCE. Once again, two separate models will be conducted for the dependent variables: internalizing behaviors and externalizing behaviors. Step 1 will include the independent variables (social cohesion, informal social control, abuse severity, neglect severity, emotional maltreatment severity) and the covariates. Step 2 will include the interaction terms (i.e., abuse severity x social cohesion, neglect severity x social cohesion, emotional maltreatment severity x social cohesion, abuse severity x informal social control, neglect severity x informal social control, emotional maltreatment severity x informal social control). 
To test whether there is a sex difference on the moderating effect of NCE, two 3-way interactions will be examined (i.e., abuse severity x NCE x sex, neglect severity x NCE x sex, and emotional maltreatment severity x NCE x sex) in Step 3 of the model. All independent variables will be in Step 1 and all 2-way interactions between abuse severity or neglect severity or emotional maltreatment severity, NCE, and sex will be in Step 2. Sex differences will be tested in two separate models, one with internalizing symptoms as the dependent variable and one with externalizing symptoms as the dependent variable.

registration_responses.q1: The role of neighborhood collective efficacy in moderating internalizing and externalizing behaviors in adolescents who experienced maltreatment
registration_responses.q3:
Child maltreatment is associated with an increased risk of adverse outcomes, including aggression, depressive symptoms, and anxiety symptoms (Cicchetti & Toth, 2005; Hildyard & Wolfe, 2002). It is important for prevention and intervention efforts to identify factors that may reduce risk of adverse outcomes in children who have experienced maltreatment. Neighborhood collective efficacy (NCE) is the perception of the social connection in the neighborhood, which includes a combination of social cohesion (i.e., trust in neighbors) and informal social control (i.e., neighbors’ willingness to intervene in situations) (Sampson et al. 1997). Neighborhood collective efficacy (NCE) is associated with lower externalizing and internalizing problems among diverse groups of individuals. The two components of NCE, informal social control and social cohesion, are uniquely associated with lower externalizing and internalizing problems (Dawson et al., 2019; Kim et al., 2019; Kingsbury et al., 2019). Social cohesion buffers the effect of stressful life events on adolescent externalizing problems (e.g., aggression) and internalizing problems (e.g., depression and anxiety) (Kingsbury 2019; Kim 2019). However, limited studies have examined moderating effect of NCE or its components on internalizing problems and externalizing problems in individuals who have experienced child maltreatment. The study is unique since we are examining the individual components of NCE and maltreatment, a potent relationship stressor. The protective effect of NCE may operate differently in the context of maltreatment compared to other types of stress. In addition, few studies have examined associations of NCE with both internalizing and externalizing behaviors in the same study.
 Research has found that higher NCE or social cohesion is related to lower externalizing behaviors among maltreated youths (Kotch et al. 2014; Yonas et al. 2010). One study found that youths who experienced neglect were buffered on aggressive outcomes by NCE but not youths who experienced physical or sexual abuse (Yonas et al. 2010). These results suggest that NCE may not buffer different types of maltreatment in the same manner. Furthermore, another study found a main effect such that higher social cohesion but not informal social control was associated with lower externalizing problems among youths who experienced neglect (Kotch et al. 2014). Additionally, there is only one study to our knowledge that has examined if neighborhood social cohesion has a moderating effect on internalizing behaviors. Using data from the Project of Human Development of Chicago Neighborhoods, the authors founds that higher neighborhood social cohesion was related to lower internalizing behaviors but not externalizing behaviors among youths that experienced physical aggression towards them by a parent (Riina, Martin, & Brooks-Gunn, 2014). It was also demonstrated that social cohesion did not buffer children younger than 11 years old from internalizing behaviors; however, this buffering effect was seen in 11-year-old children and older. 
Since Riina and colleagues’ (2014) study only had parent report about parent-child physical aggression history, it will be beneficial to examine the moderating effect of NCE in a sample that used Child Protective Services (CPS) reports such as other studies that examined externalizing behaviors (Kotch et al. 2014; Yonas et al. 2010). There are mixed findings about the potential protective effects of social cohesion and informal social control among different maltreatment types. Thus, it is important to further examine these components of NCE individually. Furthermore, there is limited work that examined how the severity of stressors might moderate the associations between NCE and adverse outcomes. One study found that although there was no direct association between NCE and externalizing symptoms, NCE did buffer externalizing behaviors among maltreated adolescents who experienced bereavement (Sasser et al., 2019). Thus, NCE might still be an effective protective factor even in the context of high stress. 
Using the Fragile Families and Child Wellbeing Study (FFCWS), a sample of nearly 5000 individuals with prospective measures of abuse and neglect behaviors from birth through adolescence, we will test the hypothesis that NCE moderates the association of maltreatment with internalizing and externalizing problems. We hypothesize that maltreatment type and severity will moderate the buffering effect of NCE. However, the FFCWS uses parent report of abuse and neglect behaviors; we will then replicate the findings from the FFCWS dataset with another dataset. The Longitudinal Studies on Child Abuse and Neglect (LONGSCAN) dataset, an agency-referred sample of approximately 1300 maltreated and at-risk youth, will be used to replicate the findings of FFCWS. The proposed analyses will increase our understanding of the potential buffering nature of NCE for youths who have experienced maltreatment.

Abuse and internalizing behaviors will not be associated with one another at higher levels of social cohesion. It is expected that at lower levels of social cohesion, there will be a positive association between abuse and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that social cohesion will not moderate the association between abuse and externalizing behaviors.
Informal social control: Informal social control is not predicted to moderate the association between neglect and externalizing behaviors or between emotional maltreatment and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that informal social control will not moderate the association between neglect and internalizing behaviors or between emotional maltreatment and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that at higher levels of informal social control, there will be no association between abuse and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of informal social control, there will be a positive association between abuse and externalizing behaviors. It is expected that at higher levels of informal social control, there will be no association between abuse and internalizing behaviors. It is expected that at lower levels of informal social control, there will be a positive association between abuse and internalizing behaviors.

Exploratory aim 3: To test whether there is a sex difference on the moderating effect of NCE between maltreatment and internalizing and externalizing behaviors at age 15 or age 16.
Hypothesis 3: There has been mixed findings on sex differences in both NCE with internalizing behaviors and externalizing behaviors. 
Internalizing behaviors: Two studies of adolescents found the moderating effect of NCE between social disorder or exposure to violence and internalizing behaviors among females (Browning et al., 2013, 2014), but another study found moderating effect of NCE between stress and internalizing problems among males only (Sharma et al., 2019). With these mixed findings, we have no a priori hypotheses on the potential sex differences on the effect of NCE between maltreatment and internalizing behaviors. 
Externalizing behaviors: Wilkinson and colleagues (2019) showed that there were no sex differences in the moderating effect of NCE on frequency of delinquent behaviors among maltreated adolescents. Thus, it is predicted that there will not be any sex differences on the moderating effect of NCE on the association between maltreatment and externalizing behaviors.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q13:
FFCWS: 
	Sample Size: A total of 4,898 mothers and 3,830 fathers were interviewed at baseline (Wave 1). A total of 4,364 mothers and 3,379 fathers were interviewed at child’s age 1 (Wave 2). A total of 4,231 mothers and 3,299 fathers were interviewed at child’s age 3 (Wave 3). In Wave 3, a primary caregiver survey was created if the child lives with their primary caregiver half the time or more. A total of 3,288 completed the primary caregiver survey. A total of 4,139 mothers, 3,159 fathers, and 2,989 primary caregivers were interviewed at child’s age 5 (Wave 4). A total of 3,515 mothers, 2,652 fathers, and 3,630 primary caregivers were interviewed at child’s age 9 (Wave 5). A total of 3,580 primary caregivers completed the interview at child’s age 15 (Wave 6). In year 3 based on mother’s response, 21.65% identified as White, non-Hispanic, 48.63% identified as Black, non-Hispanic, 25.61% identified as Hispanic, 3.53% identified as “Other” and 0.58% are missing race/ethnicity. Around 3435 adolescents completed the Brief Symptoms Inventory 18 and around 3437 adolescents completed the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale. Around 3428 adolescents completed the Delinquency Behavior questionnaire. Around 3525 primary caregivers completed the Neighborhood Collective Efficacy questionnaire. 

LONGSCAN:
	Sample Size: A total of 1354 children’s caregivers participated in this study at baseline (child’s age 4 or 6). A total of 1140 children’s caregivers participated when their child was 8 years old. A total of 976 children’s caregivers participated when their child was 12 years old. A total of 961 children’s caregivers participated when their child was 14 years old. A total of 895 children’s caregivers participated when their child was 16 years old. A total of 932 children’s caregivers participated when their child was 18 years old. A total of 552 children’s caregivers participated in all the interviews. At baseline, 53.3% identified as African American, 26.3% identified as White, 7.2% identified as Hispanic, 11.9% identified as mixed, and 1.5% identified as “other.” An overall total of 667 adolescents completed the Trauma Symptom Checklist for Children at age 16. registration_responses.q23:
15.1 FFCWS
	Participants must have at least half of their data on the abuse and neglect items to have abuse and neglect calculated. Participants with missing data on the final abuse severity variable and neglect severity variable will not be included in the analysis.
	Multiple imputation  will be used to handle missing data on the BSI 18, CES-D, delinquency measure, NCE scale, abuse variables, and neglect variables.
15.2 LONGSCAN
	Participants must have at least half of their data on the abuse and neglect items to have abuse and neglect calculated. Participants with missing data on the final abuse severity variable, neglect severity variable, and emotional maltreatment severity variable will not be included in the analysis.

registration_responses.q24:
FFCWS
Exploratory models. Stepwise linear regression models will be conducted to test the influence of 1) timing of maltreatment, 2) the separate components of NCE (i.e., social cohesion and informal social control), and 3) sex.
To test whether timing of maltreatment has an influence on the effect of NCE on internalizing and externalizing behaviors, we will calculate severity of each maltreatment type similar to the main models except we will calculate them into 2 groups: early and late. The early variable will be composed by calculating the total severity from age 1-5 for each maltreatment type while late variable will be composed by calculating the total severity from age 9-15 for each maltreatment type. The first separate stepwise linear regression model will be conducted with internalizing behaviors as the dependent variable and the second stepwise linear regression will be conducted with externalizing behavior as the dependent variable. The stepwise regressions will have step 1 all the independent variables (early abuse severity, late abuse severity, early neglect severity, late neglect severity, and NCE), including the covariates. Step 2 will include the interaction terms (i.e., early abuse severity x NCE, late abuse severity x NCE, early neglect severity x NCE, late neglect severity x NCE). 
To test whether there is a difference between the types of NCE, social cohesion and informal social control will be examined separately instead of combined as NCE. Once again, two separate models will be conducted for the dependent variables: internalizing behaviors and externalizing behaviors. Step 1 will include the independent variables (social cohesion, informal social control, abuse severity, neglect severity) and the covariates. Step 2 will include the interaction terms (i.e., abuse severity x social cohesion, neglect severity x social cohesion, abuse severity x informal social control, neglect severity x informal social control). 
To test whether there is a sex difference on the moderating effect of NCE, two 3-way interactions will be examined (i.e., abuse severity x NCE x sex, and neglect severity x NCE x sex) in Step 3 of the model. All independent variables will be in Step 1 and all 2-way interactions between abuse severity or neglect severity, NCE, and sex will be in Step 2. Sex differences will be tested in two separate models, one with internalizing symptoms as the dependent variable and one with externalizing symptoms as the dependent variable.

LONGSCAN
Exploratory models. Stepwise linear regression models will be conducted to test the influence of 1) timing of maltreatment, 2) the separate components of NCE (i.e., social cohesion and informal social control), and 3) sex.
To test whether timing of maltreatment has an influence on the effect of NCE on internalizing and externalizing behaviors, we will calculate severity of each maltreatment type similar to the main models except we will calculate them into 2 groups: early and late. The early variable will be composed by calculating the total severity from age 0-6 for each maltreatment type while late variable will be composed by calculating the total severity from age 7-16 for each maltreatment type. The first separate stepwise linear regression model will be conducted with internalizing behaviors as the dependent variable and the second stepwise linear regression will be conducted with externalizing behavior as the dependent variable. The stepwise regressions will have step 1 all the independent variables (early abuse severity, late abuse severity, early neglect severity, late neglect severity, early emotional maltreatment severity, late emotional maltreatment severity, and NCE), including the covariates. Step 2 will include the interaction terms (i.e., early abuse severity x NCE, late abuse severity x NCE, early neglect severity x NCE, late neglect severity x NCE, early emotional maltreatment severity x NCE, late emotional maltreatment severity x NCE).
To test whether there is a difference between the types of NCE, social cohesion and informal social control will be examined separately instead of combined as NCE. Once again, two separate models will be conducted for the dependent variables: internalizing behaviors and externalizing behaviors. Step 1 will include the independent variables (social cohesion, informal social control, abuse severity, neglect severity, emotional maltreatment severity) and the covariates. Step 2 will include the interaction terms (i.e., abuse severity x social cohesion, neglect severity x social cohesion, emotional maltreatment severity x social cohesion, abuse severity x informal social control, neglect severity x informal social control, emotional maltreatment severity x informal social control). 
To test whether there is a sex difference on the moderating effect of NCE, two 3-way interactions will be examined (i.e., abuse severity x NCE x sex, neglect severity x NCE x sex, and emotional maltreatment severity x NCE x sex) in Step 3 of the model. All independent variables will be in Step 1 and all 2-way interactions between abuse severity or neglect severity or emotional maltreatment severity, NCE, and sex will be in Step 2. Sex differences will be tested in two separate models, one with internalizing symptoms as the dependent variable and one with externalizing symptoms as the dependent variable.
