registration_responses.q8.question: Two secondary datasets – one longitudinal cohort study recruited at birth and followed-up at age 1, 3, 5, 9 and 15 (FFCWS); another longitudinal cohort study recruited at age 4 and followed-up at age 6, 8, 10, 12, and 16 (LONGSCAN).
registration_responses.q12.question:
FFCWS:
Data collection: The FFCWS is a large longitudinal study representative of children born in large cities in the United States. The participants were born between 1998-2000 and were recruited at birth from 20 different cities. The FFCWS prioritized recruiting unmarried mothers since the goals of this study is to understand families and children from unmarried parents.  Both parents were asked to interview. If the father did not participate in the study, then the mother was asked questions about the father. Families were interviewed after their child was born, when their child was 1-year old, 3-years-old, 5-years-old, 9-years-old, and 15-years-old. There are many measures that were examined in these interviews by parents and/or primary caregiver and child (depending on age). In the interviews, mothers and/or primary caregivers were asked about their perception of the neighborhood and maltreatment experienced by their child. The demographic questionnaire, Neighborhood Collective Efficacy scale, and the Parent-Child Conflict Tactics Scales were given to mothers and/or primary caregivers. At age 15, adolescents completed self-report measures on their anxiety symptoms, depression symptom, and delinquency behaviors. The Brief Symptoms Inventory 18, the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale, and the Delinquency Behavior questionnaire were given to adolescents.

LONGSCAN:
Data collection: The LONGSCAN is a longitudinal study following children with different levels of risk for maltreatment. Participants were recruited at age 4 years from 5 different cities. Depending on the study site, participants were either recruited from another study, recruited from a tracking program, recruited from being reported to CPS, or recruited as a control (e.g., similar neighborhood background). Three cities recruited children from already existing samples and the other cities also recruited from other groups. The goal of this study was to understand families and children that are at risk of maltreatment or have experienced maltreatment. Primary caregivers were interviewed when their child was 4-year old, 6-years-old, 8-years-old, 12-years-old, 14-years-old, and 16-years-old. Parents and/or primary caregiver and child (depending on age) were interviewed. At age 16 of the child, primary caregivers were asked about their perception of the neighborhood, the Quality of Neighborhood, Residential Stability & Organizational and Religious Affiliation questionnaire. At age 16, adolescents completed self-report questionnaires on their trauma symptoms, and their delinquent and violent behaviors. Adolescents completed the Trauma Symptom Checklist for Children, and the Delinquent and Violent Behavior measure. Additionally, CPS records were regularly reviewed from birth through age 18 and were recoded with both the National Incidence Study coding and the Modified Maltreatment Classification System (MMCS; Barnett, Manly, & Cicchetti, 1993).

registration_responses.q19.question:
Stepwise linear regression models will be conducted in both FFCWS and LONGSCAN using SPSS version 25. 

14.1 FFCWS
Main models. The FFCWS dataset will be analyzed first with the 2 main models and then 3 exploratory models. In the two main models, the following independent variables will be entered into Step 1 of the stepwise linear model: abuse severity, neglect severity, NCE, covariates. The two interactions (abuse severity x NCE, and neglect severity x NCE) will be calculated after centering abuse severity, neglect severity, and NCE at zero, and these interactions will be entered into Step 2. The first model will have internalizing behaviors as the dependent variable, and the second model will be the same as the first model except that the dependent variable will be externalizing behaviors. We will use the Johnson-Neyman procedure (D’Alonzo, K. T., 2004) to examine regions of significance for significant interactions.

14.2 LONGSCAN
Main models. The LONGSCAN dataset will be analyzed after the FFCWS analyses with the 2 main models and then 3 exploratory models to replicate the findings from FFCWS. In the two main models, the following independent variables will be entered into Step 1 of the stepwise linear model: abuse severity, neglect severity, emotional maltreatment severity, NCE, and covariates. The three two-way interactions (abuse severity x NCE, neglect severity x NCE, and emotional maltreatment severity x NCE) will be calculated after centering abuse severity, neglect severity, emotional maltreatment severity, and NCE at zero, and these interactions will be entered into Step 2. The first model will have internalizing behaviors as the dependent variable, and the second model will be the same as the first model except that the dependent variable will be externalizing behaviors. We will use the Johnson-Neyman procedure (D’Alonzo, K. T., 2004) to examine regions significance for significant interactions.

attributes.title: Validating Point Process Models for Use in Ecological Momentary Assessment Research on Infrequent Human Behaviors

summary.value:
Emotion researchers have recently begun to conceptualize emotion regulation as an interaction between the person, the situation, and the emotion regulation strategy itself (Doré, Silvers, & Ochsner, 2016). Ecological momentary assessment (EMA) affords researchers the opportunity to capture information across all three of these domains simultaneously: using mobile smartphone technology, participants can report their naturally occurring use of different strategies within different situations, over time. While EMA methodology provides many benefits (Aldao, 2013; Shiffman, Stone, & Hufford, 2008), these rich sources of data can be challenging to analyze with more traditional statistical approaches (e.g., regression, ANOVA) due to their high dimensionality. Namely, there is a virtually infinite number of strategies that people can use and situations that people can encounter within daily life, with an extraordinary number of potential combinations. In this way, the occurrence of any one strategy within any one situation is quite rare, making it challenging to establish robust inferential statistics that are calculated using methods that assume normality and linear underlying processes of the data systems. Thus, while theory championing the importance of person-situation-strategy interactions has grown over the past decade (e.g., Aldao, Sheppes, & Gross, 2015; Bonanno & Burton, 2013), empirical studies that test such three-way interactions have lagged behind (see Doré et al., 2016 for review). Clearly, there is a need to develop new approaches to analyze these rich but sparse EMA data.

Point process models are used to model any series of discrete events over time. They describe “the probability of a new event in the next instant of time, given knowledge of the past up until the present” (Harte, 2015, p. 2). Conditional only on the history of the system (i.e., how the system has behaved since initiating data collection) and time (i.e., the point in time for which each data point was collected relative to the initial data point), point process models can accommodate data that are heavily zero-inflated. Thus, point process models allow researchers to model rare events. Up until this point, their use has largely been confined to meteorological contexts (e.g., lightening striking the ground, a volcano erupting, the onset of an earthquake; Schoenberg, nd) and neuron spiking. However, it is likely that these models can be applied to other types of rare events, such as emotion regulation strategy use across different situations in daily life. Therefore, this methodological paper aims to validate the use of point process models for studying emotion regulation in EMA data. Although this study focuses on emotion regulation strategy use, it is but one example of “rare” human behavior that can be measured through EMA. As EMA research continues to grow in popularity, both within and outside of emotion regulation content, it is vital to uncover appropriate analytic approaches that researchers can use to handle infrequently occurring phenomena.

Method

To our knowledge, point process models have not yet been applied to EMA data. Given the goal of this paper is to validate an existing analytic approach on a new type of data source, we will follow methods previously established by Ogata (1988), Vere-Jones (2009) and Wadsworth and Tawn (2012). Given this paper is methodologically motivated rather than theoretically motivated, we use this pre-registration to briefly outline the steps that we propose to take on a previously collected EMA dataset, including a validation on simulated data and an application demonstration within real human subjects data (described below). This dataset measured 144 participants’ use of eight different emotion regulation strategies over the course of two weeks. Participants reported using (or not using) each of these strategies up to six times a day in response to semi-randomly timed short mobile phone surveys. 

For each individual, we will fit multiple models (e.g., exponential, loglinear, linear) to their self-reported use of the eight strategies to estimate different types of “growth” (i.e., is a person more likely to use a strategy at the next survey after it was already used, less likely to use a strategy at the next survey after it was already used, or no more or no less likely to use a strategy at the next survey after it was already used?). Note that each strategy will be modeled separately, per person. Idiographic models, such as these, allow researchers to harness the full information that is collected on a given individual, across time, rather than averaging/collapsing across potentially meaningful within-person differences (as is done in traditional aggregate approaches). So, point process modelling will allow researchers to treat intra-individual differences as meaningful rather than as noise. Although idiographic models are less generalizable than aggregate models, accounting for individual trajectories in strategy use is particularly important in this context, given that time-varying situations are expected to interact with strategy use and trait-level characteristics (Doré et al., 2016). Further, there are multiple clinical applications of this work that would involve modifying emotion regulation strategy choices at the individual level over time. 

We will compare the model fit statistics for each strategy for each person and select the best fitting model to represent the growth trajectory of each underlying system (in this case, “system” refers to an individual’s use of a given strategy over time). Note that if there are no fit differences between the models, we will assume the process in stable and linear to simplify the model parameters. If the best fit model to any given system is linear, it will be considered homogenous. A homogenous system tells you the expected rate of that strategy being used across all time (and can be interpreted similarly to a probability value). Systems that are better characterized by a non-linear process (i.e., exponential, loglinear) will be considered non-homogenous. Non-homogenous systems generally can then be transformed to homogenous systems so that all systems can be accurately compared together (regardless of if all systems share the same underlying growth parameters within the raw EMA data). While non-homogenous systems will be transformed to homogenous systems in order to directly compare the use of different strategies and different people, such differences in underlying growth processes between people are likely substantively meaningful rather than a result of noise. For example, if Person A’s use of a cognitive reappraisal strategy is characterized by a loglinear process whereas Person B’s use of cognitive reappraisal is characterized by an exponential process, this difference suggests that Person A becomes less likely to use cognitive reappraisal after they have used it while Person B becomes more likely to use cognitive reappraisal after they have used it. As such, these differences in growth processes across participants (or differences across strategy types within a given participant) could point to important individual differences that would otherwise be washed out by statistical methods that assume that all data are generated by an identical underlying process. 

Note that this approach allows for potentially important covariates to be included in the models. For example, how effective the individual viewed their strategy attempt to be in helping to improve their thoughts and feelings could reasonably impact the rate at which that strategy re-occurs for the individual. While the current methodologically-focused paper will explore the simplest case of point process models on complex human data, point process models can include additional variables of theoretical interest to allow applied researchers to test substantive questions of interest. 

Validation Approach

To validate point process modeling on EMA data, we will simulate data that imitates those that are often observed in psychological EMA data (e.g., unequal spacing between observation points, binary outcomes with zero inflation, unequal measurement points across participants). We will generate these simulated data according to different underlying processes (i.e., some simulated data streams will be generated according to a linear process, while others will be simulated according to log-linear or exponential processes). After simulating data for which we know the underlying process, we will test to see if the point process models, according to our proposed steps, recover these known processes. If the models recover the underlying processes that are known to have generated the simulated data, we will have demonstrated validation.

Demonstrating Application

To demonstrate application in real data, we will test a substantive hypothesis. Point process models return values that characterize the rate of occurrence of a given phenomenon. In the literature, social anxiety disorder symptom severity has been negatively associated with the tendency to use cognitive reappraisal, at both trait and state levels (Blalock, Kashdan, & Farmer, 2016). Thus, it is possible that social anxiety symptom severity influences the rate of occurrence (and recurrence) of cognitive reappraisal in daily life. Therefore, we hypothesize that social anxiety symptom severity, as measured by the Social Interaction Anxiety Scale (Mattick & Clarke, 1998), will be associated with cognitive reappraisal rate of occurrence over time. Note that we do not make claims about the direction of this predicted effect (successful use of cognitive reappraisal could decrease the rate of its future occurrence based on a diminished need to regulate or increase the rate of its future occurrence based on a tendency to use what has worked in the past). Also note that a null result should not be interpreted as a failed validation of this modeling approach, as well-validated models often return null results. 

To further show the applicability of these models, we will take each time series and fit a point process model to the first 70% of the data points. We will then use this training data set to see how accurately these models can predict the rate of occurrence of the remaining 30% of the data using 95%-confidence intervals. If a large proportion of individuals’ strategy-use rate of occurrence is contained within these 95%-confidence intervals (i.e., approximately 85% of the data or above), then we will conclude that this method shows good feasibility/applicability to data derived from EMA studies. If less than 85% of the data is included within these 95%-confidence intervals, then we can conclude that our model is likely not very applicable to this system.

Extended Application

Ultimately, we are interested in combining simultaneous streams of information (i.e., multiple emotion regulation strategies and situational contexts – such as in-the-moment affect, perceived effectiveness of the strategy in that moment, being alone or with others, et cetera – that are often measured within the emotion regulation-focused EMA studies) to investigate the reciprocal relationship between context and strategy use within and across people. This approach will require a multivariate approach to applying point process models to EMA data (where the outcome would be a matrix of all eight strategies). Due to the complexity of multivariate point process models, we will need to iteratively refine these models through application to the data. While challenging to pre-register, we will openly share and detail all decisions that were made in this process.

To our knowledge, point process models have not yet been applied to EMA data. Given the goal of this paper is to validate an existing analytic approach on a new type of data source, we will follow methods previously established by Ogata (1988), Vere-Jones (2009) and Wadsworth and Tawn (2012). Given this paper is methodologically motivated rather than theoretically motivated, we use this pre-registration to briefly outline the steps that we propose to take on a previously collected EMA dataset, including a validation on simulated data and an application demonstration within real human subjects data (described below). This dataset measured 144 participants’ use of eight different emotion regulation strategies over the course of two weeks. Participants reported using (or not using) each of these strategies up to six times a day in response to semi-randomly timed short mobile phone surveys. 

For each individual, we will fit multiple models (e.g., exponential, loglinear, linear) to their self-reported use of the eight strategies to estimate different types of “growth” (i.e., is a person more likely to use a strategy at the next survey after it was already used, less likely to use a strategy at the next survey after it was already used, or no more or no less likely to use a strategy at the next survey after it was already used?). Note that each strategy will be modeled separately, per person. Idiographic models, such as these, allow researchers to harness the full information that is collected on a given individual, across time, rather than averaging/collapsing across potentially meaningful within-person differences (as is done in traditional aggregate approaches). So, point process modelling will allow researchers to treat intra-individual differences as meaningful rather than as noise. Although idiographic models are less generalizable than aggregate models, accounting for individual trajectories in strategy use is particularly important in this context, given that time-varying situations are expected to interact with strategy use and trait-level characteristics (Doré et al., 2016). Further, there are multiple clinical applications of this work that would involve modifying emotion regulation strategy choices at the individual level over time. 

We will compare the model fit statistics for each strategy for each person and select the best fitting model to represent the growth trajectory of each underlying system (in this case, “system” refers to an individual’s use of a given strategy over time). Note that if there are no fit differences between the models, we will assume the process in stable and linear to simplify the model parameters. If the best fit model to any given system is linear, it will be considered homogenous. A homogenous system tells you the expected rate of that strategy being used across all time (and can be interpreted similarly to a probability value). Systems that are better characterized by a non-linear process (i.e., exponential, loglinear) will be considered non-homogenous. Non-homogenous systems generally can then be transformed to homogenous systems so that all systems can be accurately compared together (regardless of if all systems share the same underlying growth parameters within the raw EMA data). While non-homogenous systems will be transformed to homogenous systems in order to directly compare the use of different strategies and different people, such differences in underlying growth processes between people are likely substantively meaningful rather than a result of noise. For example, if Person A’s use of a cognitive reappraisal strategy is characterized by a loglinear process whereas Person B’s use of cognitive reappraisal is characterized by an exponential process, this difference suggests that Person A becomes less likely to use cognitive reappraisal after they have used it while Person B becomes more likely to use cognitive reappraisal after they have used it. As such, these differences in growth processes across participants (or differences across strategy types within a given participant) could point to important individual differences that would otherwise be washed out by statistical methods that assume that all data are generated by an identical underlying process. 

Note that this approach allows for potentially important covariates to be included in the models. For example, how effective the individual viewed their strategy attempt to be in helping to improve their thoughts and feelings could reasonably impact the rate at which that strategy re-occurs for the individual. While the current methodologically-focused paper will explore the simplest case of point process models on complex human data, point process models can include additional variables of theoretical interest to allow applied researchers to test substantive questions of interest. 

Validation Approach

To validate point process modeling on EMA data, we will simulate data that imitates those that are often observed in psychological EMA data (e.g., unequal spacing between observation points, binary outcomes with zero inflation, unequal measurement points across participants). We will generate these simulated data according to different underlying processes (i.e., some simulated data streams will be generated according to a linear process, while others will be simulated according to log-linear or exponential processes). After simulating data for which we know the underlying process, we will test to see if the point process models, according to our proposed steps, recover these known processes. If the models recover the underlying processes that are known to have generated the simulated data, we will have demonstrated validation.

Demonstrating Application

To demonstrate application in real data, we will test a substantive hypothesis. Point process models return values that characterize the rate of occurrence of a given phenomenon. In the literature, social anxiety disorder symptom severity has been negatively associated with the tendency to use cognitive reappraisal, at both trait and state levels (Blalock, Kashdan, & Farmer, 2016). Thus, it is possible that social anxiety symptom severity influences the rate of occurrence (and recurrence) of cognitive reappraisal in daily life. Therefore, we hypothesize that social anxiety symptom severity, as measured by the Social Interaction Anxiety Scale (Mattick & Clarke, 1998), will be associated with cognitive reappraisal rate of occurrence over time. Note that we do not make claims about the direction of this predicted effect (successful use of cognitive reappraisal could decrease the rate of its future occurrence based on a diminished need to regulate or increase the rate of its future occurrence based on a tendency to use what has worked in the past). Also note that a null result should not be interpreted as a failed validation of this modeling approach, as well-validated models often return null results. 

To further show the applicability of these models, we will take each time series and fit a point process model to the first 70% of the data points. We will then use this training data set to see how accurately these models can predict the rate of occurrence of the remaining 30% of the data using 95%-confidence intervals. If a large proportion of individuals’ strategy-use rate of occurrence is contained within these 95%-confidence intervals (i.e., approximately 85% of the data or above), then we will conclude that this method shows good feasibility/applicability to data derived from EMA studies. If less than 85% of the data is included within these 95%-confidence intervals, then we can conclude that our model is likely not very applicable to this system.

Extended Application

Ultimately, we are interested in combining simultaneous streams of information (i.e., multiple emotion regulation strategies and situational contexts – such as in-the-moment affect, perceived effectiveness of the strategy in that moment, being alone or with others, et cetera – that are often measured within the emotion regulation-focused EMA studies) to investigate the reciprocal relationship between context and strategy use within and across people. This approach will require a multivariate approach to applying point process models to EMA data (where the outcome would be a matrix of all eight strategies). Due to the complexity of multivariate point process models, we will need to iteratively refine these models through application to the data. While challenging to pre-register, we will openly share and detail all decisions that were made in this process.

attributes.title: The effect of (social) support on physical pain
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value: One independent variable with two conditions and between participants design

question2b.value:
Manipulation check
The rating of Physical Pain felt by participants

question10b.value:
After the demographic questions (gender, education, nationality) participants will be invited to the lab to and randomly will be assigned to one of the social support conditions (mental stimulation vs. real one) and then instructed to place their nondominant hand into the water, which was maintained at 1 to 2°C. Participants will be instructed to refrain from moving their hand while it was immersed and to keep their hand in the water until the sensations became too uncomfortable. Participants will keep hand immersed until they removed it or until 3 minutes had elapsed. Thus, participants in the mental stimulation condition will be asked to look to a picture of their romantic partner whereas participants in the real support condition will be able to hold their partner’s hand!
Participants will rate how much pain they felt (after they stop or after 3 mins has elapsed) by pointing to a number on a 10-point scale, where 1   none and 10   extreme.  We will ask concerning manipulation check as described above!

question4b.value: They will be invited to participate in the study for a particular price. So it will be a lab study in which participants will be randomly assigned to one of the experimental conditions!

question5b.value: From overall Switzerland through public notification around the country!

question6b.value: A priori power analysis using Gpower for one way ANOVA with an effect size between small and medium; f= .20, alpha - 0.05, power = 0.80 with two groups indicated that for this study we will need 200 people.

question7b.value: Three minutes for experimental manipulation (see Brown, Sheffield, Leary, & Robinson, 2003) and then 3 minutes regarding the Manipulation check and the DV

question8b.value: Participants who do the experimental manipulation less than three minutes (see Brown et al., 2003) will be excluded from the analysis!

question9b.value: Well since we are talking about physical pain we first need ethical approval and then, if participants do not feel ok with the process of manipulation they should stop whenever they want!

question1a.value:
Viewing romantic parent's picture reduce physical pain similarly as holding partners hand
So it will be one hypothesis in which social support will be the independent variable and physical pain the dependent one.

question2a.value: There were not be a moderating variable.

question3a.value: We will also ask participants to write down or circle what on what they were focused on during the experimental manipulation in order to see whether our experimental manipulation worked as expected.

question5a.value: Previous research has shown that social support helps people to feel less pain even including physical pain (see Cogan & Spinnato, 1988; Kulik & Mahler, 1989; Brown, Sheffield, Leary, & Robinson, 2003) thus it will be interesting to investigate whether a mental stimulation of social support as compared to real (in person) support will be able to show the same effect (i.e., reducing the physical pain).

question1c.value: We will test the direct effect of social support (mental stimulation vs. real one) on the reduction of physical pain!

question2c.value: One way ANOVA with the experimental manipulation with 2 levels

question3c.value:
Social support = IV
Physical Pain = DV
